description: Clipping of navigator, in reference to the navigation canals upon which these workers first toiled, + -y.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Britain) A laborer on a civil engineering project such as a canal or railroad.
examples: Suppose two lads, fresh from school, go out into the world to earn their living; one becomes a navvy and one a clerk. In five years' time these two young men will probably be very different in appearance from one another. The navvy will have developed his muscles; he will be broad-built, broad-chested, and strong.

verbs.description: navvy (third-person singular simple present navvies, present participle navvying, simple past and past participle navvied)

entries.meaning: (Britain, intransitive) To carry out physical labor on a civil engineering project.
examples: But by pretending to believe he's navvied before, I've given him double reason to drive himself hard.
